Award.AwardTitle: Elucidating Length and Time Scales of Spatiotemporal Heterogeneity in Supercooled Liquids
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Laura Kaufman, together with her postdoctoral associates, graduate students, and undergraduate researchers at Columbia University will investigate fundamental aspects of spatiotemporal heterogeneity in small molecule and simulated model supercooled liquids. The proposed experiments will employ a set of carefully chosen probe molecules that allow for systematic interrogation of the length and time scales of heterogeneity in a variety of small molecule glass formers. These measurements will detail the spatial and temporal extents of heterogeneity in particular supercooled liquids and may suggest underlying connections between supercooled liquid fragility and breadth of spatiotemporal heterogeneity. Beyond typical supercooled liquids, experiments on systems that display similar phenomenology but are suspected of possessing structural heterogeneity are proposed. In addition to these measurements that monitor single molecule (SM) probe rotational dynamics, experiments that directly interrogate translational diffusion at the SM level will be undertaken. Simultaneous tracking of rotations and translations will resolve questions regarding the poorly understood phenomenon of rotational-translational decoupling in supercooled liquids, revealing whether this behavior can exist on a single molecule level. Accompanying carefully crafted simulations will allow for both rotational and translational motility to be tracked in analogy with the proposed experiments and will investigate reciprocal probe-host interactions in a manner that will inform and strengthen interpretation of experimental results.

Achieving a fuller understanding of spatiotemporal heterogeneity in supercooled liquids is of great fundamental interest as well as of applied interest in diverse fields, from petroleum transportation to cryopreservation of cells. The proposed work will also have strong educational impact on undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers in the Kaufman laboratory as well as on younger students. Professor Kaufman has initiated a relationship with a local charter school to present lectures on complex fluids to 4th-6th grade students, collaboratively develop additional lectures with their science teacher, and translate real-time assessment tools used in this school into the General Chemistry courses at Columbia University. Through service on Columbia University's Quality of Life Committee, Professor Kaufman will facilitate dissemination of information to Columbia University science students and faculty on federal agency and University-based family friendly policies, and will assist in design, dissemination, and analysis of a study on Columbia University faculty use and perceptions of the University's family leave policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fundamental aspects of spatiotemporal heterogeneity in supercooled liquids were studied experimentally via systematic investigations of small molecule glass formers at the single molecule level. These experiments employed a set of carefully chosen and/or newly designed and synthesized probe molecules that allowed for direct interrogation of the length and time scales of heterogeneity in both small molecular and polymeric glass formers. In particular, a set of perylene diimide probes was used to study the prototypical glass former, ortho-terphenyl. This study confirmed an earlier hypothesis that probes that do not rotate sufficiently quickly cannot report the full breadth of heterogeneity in a host glass former. This study also provided bounds on the temporal persistence of regions displaying particular dynamics in this supercooled liquid. With a set of probe-dependent studies leading to a growing recognition that none of the probes we had used to date was ideal for fully elucidating details of spatiotemporal heterogeneity in supercooled liquids, we designed new probes that were demonstrated to report the full breadth of heterogeneity in supercooled ortho-terphenyl and developed, through simulations complementary to our experiments, trajectory-length dependent measurements to yield information on persistence of dynamics in particular regions of supercooled liquids beyond that we had accessed previously. Taken together, advances in experimental technique, new probes, and guiding simulations allowed us to directly demonstrate for the first time ergodicity in a small molecule and a polymeric glass former, in both cases down to the glass transition temperature, consistent with some but not all pictures of the glass transition. Such experiments have also been used to further interrogate the time scale over which regions of particular dynamics exist in supercooled liquids and have resolved seeming discrepancies between single molecule findings and earlier sub-ensemble experiments.

Alongside these experiments, technical expertise was developed that will allow study of not only rotational motions of single probe molecules in supercooled liquids but also translational ones, critical information to further understand the phenomena of rotational translational decoupling in supercooled liquids. Towards this end, both feature tracking of mobile single molecules was performed and our ability to characterize translational motion on the 10 nm length scale was confirmed. Additionally, super-resolution measurements were employed to characterize polymers with ~ 5nm resolution. Taken together, these experimental advances – validated through accompanying simulations and analysis thereof – provide the tools required to reliably report translations of probe molecules in supercooled liquids. In sum, the advances made in terms of understanding ideal data collection strategies and analysis both resolved interesting fundamental questions in supercooled liquids – through, for example, direct demonstration of ergodicity at and below the glass transition temperature – and also leave us poised for additional detailed understanding of supercooled liquids.

 

The single molecule experiments performed clarified aspects of supercooled liquid behavior that could not be well addressed by ensemble or standard sub-ensemble experiments. Moreover, our work on supercooled liquids and work demonstrating translational tracking and super-resolution imaging in polymeric systems highlights the utility of these techniques, commonly used in biological studies, for the study of complex, condensed matter systems of interest in chemistry and materials science. During the course of these studies, postdoctoral researchers, graduate students and undergraduate studies were trained in a manner leaving them well equipped to move to other areas of physical chemistry and chemical physics research if they wish because of the focus on optical microscopy techniques used across many disciplines. A  publication describing the integration of current research in the PI’s laboratory into an introductory undergraduate Chemistry laboratory course highlights the reach of these techniques and the teaching opportunities they provide. Outreach on complex materials in chemistry and physics was achieved in a variety of forums including through interactive demonstrations in an elementary school and creation and distribution of web-based learned modules.
